creator: Mache, Beata
title: Digitale Edition und Erschließung eines interreligiösen Periodikums aus dem Vormärz al s editionsphilologische Aufgabe Die  „ Unparteiische Universal - Kirchenzeitung  für die Geistlichkeit und die gebildete Weltklasse des protestantischen,  katholischen  und israelitischen Deutschlands “ (1837)
subject: Kirchengeschichte
description: Die "Universal-Kirchenzeitung" war der frühe Versuch eines gleichberechtigten interkonfessionellen Dialogs unter Beteiligung von protestantischen, katholischen und "israelitischen" Redakteuren und Autoren. Sie brachte zweimal wöchentlich "kirchliche" Nachrichten aus allen Teilen der Welt, Rezensionen sowie Aufsätze. Von Reformern begrüßt, von anderen heftig kritisiert, in Preußen umgehend verboten, stand sie, im Geist der Aufklärung, aber in antiaufklärerischer Zeit, jedoch schnell zwischen allen Stühlen und stellte ihr Erscheinen nach nur genau einem Jahrgang ein. Die "Universal-Kirchenzeitung" war eine lange Zeit rare, kaum noch zugängliche und deshalb weitgehend nicht erforschte Quelle. Die vorliegende Arbeit erschließt die 1837 in 104 Ausgaben erschienene "Universal-Kirchenzeitung" thematisch-inhaltlich, widmet sich Geschichte und Schicksal, dokumentiert detailliert die enthaltenen Beiträge und ihren Autoren. Ein eigenes Kapitel geht auf die Frage nach der jüdischen Beteiligung an diesem Projekt ein. Neben der inhaltlichen Eröffnung dieses Forschungsfeldes dokumentiert die Arbeit zugleich die ebenfalls abgeschlossene und als Netzpublikation verfügbare digitale Edition der "Universal-Kirchenzeitung" (urn:nbn:de:0230-20090410994). Dazu bringt sie eine Einführung in die Editionsphilologie, die, bezogen auf die Geisteswissenschaft, früh von einer digitalen Revolution ergriffen wurde, die überhaupt erst die Neuausgabe eines solchen Periodikums möglich machte. Bei der Neuausgabe galt es, methodische Erfordernisse zu klären, und ebenso bewährte wie zeitgemäße Mittel und Methoden digitalen Edierens zu identifizieren und anzuwenden. So geht die Arbeit einerseits auf Fragen der Langfristverfügbarkeit (URN-Verfahren) ein, die ebenso infrastrukturelle Aspekte als auch Codierungs- und Speicherformate betreffen (TEI, PDF/A). Andererseits gerät ebenso die wissenschaftliche Interoperabilität in den Blick, etwa am Beispiel von Normdaten wie der Gemeinsamen Normdatei (GND) der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek, und der Auffindbarkeit durch Techniken wie BEACON und COinS.

creator: JSSAL
title: Aksoy, H.
description: In this study, it is aimed to examine the predictive effect of grammar and vocabulary variables on writing skills of those who learn Turkish as a foreign language and to determine the significance of the variables that affect the writing skills. The study was conducted according to the relational scanning model, one of the quantitative research models. The data of the study were obtained from a total of 100 students with B1 and B2 language levels in Turkish Teaching Centers in the spring semester of the 2019-2020 academic year. In the analysis of the data obtained, descriptive statistics such as mean, t-test and one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and regression and correlation analysis from hypothesis tests were used. As a result of the study, it was observed that the students obtained a result close to the middle level in the grammar test, grammar and writing skills did not differ according to gender, but the probability value calculated for "Vocabulary" changed in favor of men. It has been seen that students at B2 language level get higher scores than students at B1 language level, level of knowledge of the language, vocabulary and writing skills levels of older age groups that favor change and increasing life expectancy in Turkey in grammar, vocabulary and writing skills has been shown to increase. It has been observed that language and vocabulary have a positive and significant effect on writing skill, and there is a positive, significant and high relationship between grammar and vocabulary.

title: Wissenschaft oder Heuchelei? – eine Antwort auf Hoven, KriPoZ 3/2021, 182

creator: JSSAL
title: TurkishMongolian Lexical Borrowings in South Asian Languages .pdf
description: Turks and the Turkish language have been in mutual relations with different languages in wide world geography throughout history. There have been approximately 2500 years of mutual linguistic interaction between Turkish and South Asian, especially South West Asian languages. This study brought loanwords and lexical elements borrowed from Turkish and Mongolian into Urdu, Punjabi, Sindhi, Pashto, and Balochi. These loanwords and lexical elements have been reconfirmed from etymology dictionaries and given alphabetically as a list. This study consists of a total of 1175 loanwords and lexical elements. There are 427 loanwords and lexical elements from Urdu, 186 from Punjabi, 145 from Sindhi, 362 from Pashto, and 55 from Balochi. Some loanwords in previous studies have been left out of the list by reconfirmation of their etymologies. Finally, we prepared tables of these loanwords and lexical elements in terms of frequency, morphology/etymology, and theme. We made interpretations of said tables. This study is the important on topic because of its collective perspective.

creator: Merisa Taranis
title: 11_Müller_Atemschaukel.csv
description: This database is derived from our project “Is there a Nobel Prize Effect? Translations After the Nobel Prize. A Quantitative Analysis of Translations of Germanophone Literature Nobel Laureates”. We have researched translations for all Germanophone Nobel Prize laureates in literature. We have researched up to the year 2022 and we have included all translations that were available for research. Native speakers or team members fluent in the languages Armenian, Chinese, Croatian, English, French, Italian, Russian, Spanish, Serbo-Croatian, and Turkish controlled the catalogues in the relevant languages. Additional translations are taken from the large yet incomplete catalogues of the Deutsche Nationalbibliothek and Worldcat. Unfortunately, the Index Translationum website was offline during our research (approx. winter 2019 – winter 2021). First, we collected our data in simple Excel-formats with metadata on translators, titles of translations, year and place of printing, and languages. We treated each new edition as a new translation for our data. We decided to publish the links to the data sheets with the aforementioned metadata for GeoBrowser (https://geobrowser.de.dariah.eu/). The data in these tables is freely accessible for further analysis. We chose one work for each author that we considered particularly relevant (for control purposes, however, we researched two works each for Böll and Hesse). We created a separate data set for each author. In order to have a comparative corpus, we also included three authors who did not receive a Nobel Prize (Zweig, Bernhard, Bachmann).

creator: Nanette Rißler-Pipka
title: Cervantes_P-1616-Los trabajos de Persiles y Sigismunda.txt
subject: Hispanistik
description: This collection of literary works contains texts of several different genre and authors from the 16th to 17th century in Spain (in catellano). Detailled information regarding the genres and bibliographic references are given in the metadata table. The collection was created for the papers: "Avellaneda y los problemas de la identificación del autor. Propuestas para una investigación con nuevas herramientas digitales" (https://nbn-resolving.org/urn:nbn:de:bvb:384-opus4-37049) and "Die Digitalisierung des goldenen Zeitalters – Editionsproblematik und stilometrische Autorschaftsattribution am Beispiel des Quijote" (doi:10.17175/2018_004). All in all 96 texts are coming from public domain and different digital libraries, mostly the Biblioteca Virtual Miguel de Cervantes or Wikisource. They were transferred into plain text format (UTF-8) but only minimally cleaned. Some of the texts still have paratexts (prelimanary notes, dedications etc.

creator: Autorinnen und Autoren des Siglo de Oro
title: Textos literarios del Siglo de Oro
subject: Romanistik
description: Esta es una colección de textos literarios, escritos por varios autores del siglo de oro y pertenecientes a diferentes géneros literarios. Los fuentes bibliográficos y los géneros literarios son listados en la tabla de metadatos. Fue creada y analizada en los artículos "Die Digitalisierung des goldenen Zeitalters – Editionsproblematik und stilometrische Autorschaftsattribution am Beispiel des Quijote" (doi:10.17175/2018_004) y „Avellaneda y los problemas de la identificación del autor. Propuestas para una investigación con nuevas herramientas digitales" (https://nbn-resolving.org/urn:nbn:de:bvb:384-opus4-37049). Los 96 textos se encuentran en dominio público, son de acceso libre y la mayoría de ellos proceden de la Biblioteca Virtual Miguel de Cervantes o de Wikisource. Los textos han sido modificados mínimamente (por ejemplo en eliminando la cabacera o carácteres especiales) y convertidos en texto plano (txt, con codificación UTF-8). En algunos casos todavía se encuentran ciertos paratextos, por ejemplo al comienzo del texto. Los archivos se encuentran tal y como fueron utilizados en proyectos anteriores, por lo que los nombres de los documentos no están normalizados.

creator: orcid.org/0000-0002-0719-9003
title: Literarische Werke des Spanischen Goldenen Zeitalters
description: Diese Textsammlung enthält literarische Werke unterschiedlicher Gattungen und Autoren in spanischer Originalsprache aus dem Zeitraum des 16. bis 17. Jahrhunderts. Die Sammlung wurde anlässlich zweier stilometrischer Studien zur Autorschaft des "Quijote apocrífo" erstellt: "Avellaneda y los problemas de la identificación del autor. Propuestas para una investigación con nuevas herramientas digitales" (https://nbn-resolving.org/urn:nbn:de:bvb:384-opus4-37049) und "Die Digitalisierung des goldenen Zeitalters – Editionsproblematik und stilometrische Autorschaftsattribution am Beispiel des Quijote" (doi:10.17175/2018_004). Die insgesamt 96 Texte sind gemeinfrei zugänglich und wurden aus unterschiedlichen digitalen Bibliotheken gesammelt. Zum großen Teil stammen die Texte von Biblioteca Virtual Miguel Cervantes oder Wikisource. Zur Sammlung wird eine Metadatentabelle mit bibliographischen Angaben und Informationen zu den Gattungen veröffentlicht. Die Texte liegen im Reintextformat (UTF-8 codiert) vor und wurden nur minimal bereinigt. Es befinden sich z.T. noch Paratexte (Vorwort, Widmung, etc.) in den einzelnen Textdateien. Die Benennung der Dateien entspricht leider keinem einheitlichen Prinzip, weil sie für unterschiedliche digitale Untersuchungen verwendet wurden.

Los archivos se encuentran tal y como fueron utilizados en proyectos anteriores, por lo que los nombres de los documentos no están normalizados.

creator: Astghik Antonyan
title: 5.1_Hesse_Glasperlenspiel.csv
description: This database is derived from our project “Is there a Nobel Prize Effect? Translations After the Nobel Prize. A Quantitative Analysis of Translations of Germanophone Literature Nobel Laureates”. We have researched translations for all Germanophone Nobel Prize laureates in literature. We have researched up to the year 2022 and we have included all translations that were available for research. Native speakers or team members fluent in the languages Armenian, Chinese, Croatian, English, French, Italian, Russian, Spanish, Serbo-Croatian, and Turkish controlled the catalogues in the relevant languages. Additional translations are taken from the large yet incomplete catalogues of the Deutsche Nationalbibliothek and Worldcat. Unfortunately, the Index Translationum website was offline during our research (approx. winter 2019 – winter 2021). First, we collected our data in simple Excel-formats with metadata on translators, titles of translations, year and place of printing, and languages. We treated each new edition as a new translation for our data. We decided to publish the links to the data sheets with the aforementioned metadata for GeoBrowser (https://geobrowser.de.dariah.eu/). The data in these tables is freely accessible for further analysis. We chose one work for each author that we considered particularly relevant (for control purposes, however, we researched two works each for Böll and Hesse). We created a separate data set for each author. In order to have a comparative corpus, we also included three authors who did not receive a Nobel Prize (Zweig, Bernhard, Bachmann).

creator: JSSAL
title: Avwerhota et al., (2022
description: This cross-sectional survey conducted in southwestern Nigeria examined the common antisocial activities among adolescents and students in developing countries, using a structured questionnaire among 300 people preparing to get married. The study was conducted from September to October 2019 with an aim to the perception of people intending to marry on eradicating students and adolescents’ antisocial behavior in developing countries. Data were analyzed with IBM-SPSS version-25. Promiscuity (41.7%) topped the list of antisocial activities mentioned, followed by indecent dressing and social nuisance (27.0%). Improper parental guidance ranked highest (41.3%) as the perceived cause of antisocial and high-risk behaviors, followed by peer pressure (29.3%). Around 48% of the respondents said the parents were to blame and 26.0% said adolescents, and 15.0% said the government was to blame. Antisocial behaviors can be reduced among students and adolescents by including parenting and moral training in the education curriculum. Also, there is a need to educate parents on the essential parenting tips and methods.

creator: Marlena Sophie Luth
title: War on Ukraine Talks
description: The table “Talks at the International Level With Ukraine And/Or Russia in the Wake Of/During the War in Ukraine” lists all (high-)level international talks with Ukraine and/or Russia during March 2022. A list of talks from December 2021 till February 2022 is also available and can be shared. The table includes only talks that discuss the topic of war in Ukraine as well as negotiations that has been held in the wake of the war. The table shows the date, the participants, the involved countries, the format of the talks as well as the location. <br>For creating this table, three sources have been researched: The online database “Factiva” was used as a basis for the research. For further research, the website of the Foreign Ministry of Russia as well as the Twitter channel of the Foreign Ministry of Ukraine were analysed. 205 conversations could be identified with these sources.

creator: Areti Demosthenous
title: Protest actions in Belarus 1997-2020
description: The aim of this data collection is to present the protest actions in Belarus from 01 January 1997 until 31 December 2020. This database lists 545 protest actions in total. The data are based on a comprehensive search in multiple international news agencies via the Factiva service. The data set covers all identified protest events that contain an explicit information on the number of participants (including descriptions like “dozens”) and that had more than ten participants.

creator: Nanette Rißler-Pipka
title: Revistas culturales map - DARIAH-DE Geo-Browser data
subject: Romanistik, Lateinamerikanistik, Cultural Studies
description: This dataset (kml file) was created in 2014 using the DARIAH-DE Geo-Browser to visualise a bibliography of Spanish and Hispanic cultural magazines from 1821-1991 focusing on the period 1850-1950. The data refers to the title of the magazines, the place of publication and the publication period - if given - also the names of the editors. The bibliography was created in preparation of the revistas-culturales project (https://www.revistas-culturales.de/es) led by Hanno Ehrlicher at the University of Augsburg, now hosted at the University of Tübingen. In order to preserve the data and publish it independently from the project's website, we decided to publish it in a trusted repository which allows a direct connection to the DARIAH-DE Geo-Browser (via the Switchboard). To reuse the data you can also upload the kml file directly to the Geo-Browser: https://geobrowser.de.dariah.eu/ (to be able to do so you need login with your institutional or a DARIAH account).

creator: Center for Political Sociology (Kyiv), Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation (Kyiv)
title: How the War Changed the Way Ukrainians Think About Friends, Enemies, and the Country's Strategic Goals (Public Opinion poll by the Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation)
description: The Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation (Kyiv) conducted a face-to-face poll in cooperation with the Center for Political Sociology (Kyiv) from 07 to 15 May 2022 in seven western and four central regions of Ukraine. 1,000 respondents were interviewed at the place of their permanent residence. Migrants/refugees/IDPs were not included. The poll does not reflect the opinion of the population of the unsampled central, southern and eastern regions of Ukraine which are most affected by the war.<br><br>The 62 questions of the poll cover the topics of Ukraine's friends and enemies, the country's strategic goals plus basic socio-demographic and identity-related indicators.<br><br>The SPSS file contains the original Ukrainian wording of the questions. The original Ukrainian questionnaire togehter with an English translation is available as seperate file (questionnaire.pdf). This file is also needed if the Excel-version of the raw data (converted file format) is used.

creator: Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation, Razumkov Centre
title: The Political Mood in Ukraine (Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation)
description: This data collection offers a representative omnibus survey of the Ukrainian population, living in territories controlled by the Ukrainian government without ongoing armed hostilities. The survey was conducted by the Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation together with the sociological service of the Razumkov Center from 05 to 12 August 2022.<br><br>This data collection contains the original survey data. The SPSS file (.sav) is the original file provided by the Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation. It has been exported into an Excel file. The content of the respective xlsx-file should be identical with the original sav-file. <br><br>The sav-file contains the questions and answer options of the original questionnaire in Ukrainian. The original questionnaire is also included in this data collection as separate pdf-file. Additionally, the data collection contains the file "SelectedResults" which documents some major results of the survey in the form of analytical summaries and descriptive statistics in English.<br><br>An English translation of the questionnaire is currently in preparation and will be published as part of a future version of this data collection.

creator: Daniel Biro
title: 01_Basistexte.zip
description: Dieser Ordner enthält Textdateien, die nach der Bearbeitung der Digitalisate durch eine OCR-Software (ABBYY FineReader Engine) bzw. durch Umwandlung der heruntergeladenen PDF-Dateien entstanden sind. Jede Datei beinhaltet jeweils einen Text und alle Texte wurden an die aktuelle rumänische Orthographie angepasst (Stand 2021; Texteditor AutoCorect Version 4.1.5, Cosmin Ciuperca und Daniel Morlova von SoftSet) ). Die Dateien wurden auf zehn Subkorpora aufgeteilt, die sich jeweils einem Sprecher und einem historischen Abschnitt zuordnen lassen (Aufteilung am Ende der README-Datei).

creator: Daniel Biro
title: 05_Sentimentanalyse_mikro
description: Dieser Ordner beinhaltet zwanzig Listen mit Concgrams, die mit dem Romanian Emotion Lexicon abgeglichen wurden. Zu jedem der zehn Subkorpora existieren jeweils zwei Dateien: eine Datei mit Concgrams, in denen mindestens eine Wortform mit der Emotion Vertrauen assoziiert werden kann, und eine Datei mit Concgrams, in denen mindestens eine Wortform mit der Emotion Abneigung assoziiert werden kann.

creator: Daniel Biro
title: 03_Sentimentanalyse_makro.zip
description: Dieser Ordner enthält die Textdateien nach einem Abgleich mit dem digitalen Romanian Emotion Lexicon, das an der Babeș-Bolyai-Universität in Cluj-Napoca von Mihaiela Lupea und Annamaria Briciu erstellt wurde. Vor dem Abgleich wurden Sätze, die Negationen beinhalten, sowie Auxiliarverben entfernt. Die Dateien enthalten nur die relevanten Wortarten (Adjektiv, Adverb, Interjektion, Substantiv, Verb), die mit einem Großbuchstaben zu Beginn eines jeden Lemmas markiert sind. Die Annotationen der Polarität und Emotionen sind in einer Klammer hinter dem Lemma mit Ziffern markiert (0 = Negativität, 1 = Positivität, 2 = Vertrauen, 3 = Angst, 4 = Überraschung, 5 = Traurigkeit, 6 = Abneigung, 7 = Ärger, 8 = Erwartung, 9 = Freude).

creator: Daniel Biro
title: 02_PoS.zip
description: Dieser Ordner enthält die lemmatisierten Texte mit Part-of-Speech-Annotationen. Für die Annotation wurde die Open-Source-Software TreeTagger genutzt, die von Helmut Schmid im TC-Projekt des Instituts für Computerlinguistik der Universität Stuttgart entwickelt wurde. Das Tool sowie Parameter für zahlreiche Sprachen stehen u. a. auf der Webseite des Centrums für Informations- und Sprachverarbeitung der LMU München zur Verfügung: https:// www.cis.uni-muenchen.de/~schmid/tools/TreeTagger/ [Letzter Zugriff am 16.01.2023]. Die Dateien wurden auf zehn Subkorpora aufgeteilt, die sich jeweils einem Sprecher und einem historischen Abschnitt zuordnen lassen (Aufteilung am Ende der README-Datei).

creator: Daniel Biro
title: mikro_10_KJ_Abneigung.csv
description: Auflistung der anhand der Basistexte verifizierten Okkurrenzen der frequentesten Concgrams (frequente Wortkombinationen innerhalb einer bestimmten Wortspanne) aus 05_Sentimentanalyse_mikro in Subkorpus 10_KJ bezüglich der Emotion Abneigung. Alle verifizierten Okkurrenzen sind in 06_Okkurrenzen zu finden.

creator: Daniel Biro
title: 06_Okkurrenzen_Vertrauen.zip
description: Die Dateien in diesem Ordner beinhalten die anhand der Basistexte verifizierten Okkurrenzen der frequentesten Concgrams aus 05_Sentimentanalyse_mikro. Die Ordner teilen die Dateien erneut in die zehn Subkorpora und anschließend in Concgrams in Assoziation mit Vertrauen bzw. Abneigung auf.

creator: Daniel Biro
title: mikro_02_GG_Vertrauen.csv
description: Auflistung der anhand der Basistexte verifizierten Okkurrenzen der frequentesten Concgrams (frequente Wortkombinationen innerhalb einer bestimmten Wortspanne) aus 05_Sentimentanalyse_mikro in Subkorpus 02_GG bezüglich der Emotion Vertrauen. Alle verifizierten Okkurrenzen sind in 06_Okkurrenzen zu finden.

creator: Daniel Biro
title: makro_Polaritat-Emotionen_Reden-Formate.csv
description: Absolute und prozentuale Anzahl von Negativität, Positivität und Gesamtemotionen (acht Basisemotionen) in Reden (vermeintlich geplante Texte) und Formaten (vermeintlich spontane Texte).

creator: Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation, Razumkov Centre
title: Omnibus Poll Ukraine (Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation)
description: This data collection offers a representative omnibus survey of the Ukrainian population, living in territories controlled by the Ukrainian government without ongoing armed hostilities. The survey was conducted by the Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation together with the sociological service of the Razumkov Center from 13 to 21 December 2022.<br><br>This data collection contains the original survey data. The SPSS file (.sav) is the original file provided by the Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation. It has been exported into an Excel file. The content of the respective xlsx-file should be identical with the original sav-file. The sav-file contains the questions and answer options of the original questionnaire in Ukrainian. The original questionnaire is also included in this data collection as separate pdf-file. An English translation of the questionnaire is currently in preparation and will be added to the next version of this data collection. The "info"-file in this data collection provides a description of the survey design.<br><br>Additionally, the data collection contains two files with "selected results" which document some major results of the survey in the form of a analytical summaries and descriptive statistics in English.

creator: Tomasz Piędzioch
title: Ocena działalności Pierwszego Kongresu Kontynentalnego na podstawie pierwszej polemiki Aleksandra Hamiltona z Samuelem Seasbury
description: W 1774 r. po zwołaniu Pierwszego Kongresu Kontynentalnego w społeczeństwie Trzynastu Kolonii trwała debata na temat zakresu wolności kolonii względem metropolii. Decyzje podjęte przez Kongres w Filadelfii spotkały się z mieszanym odbiorem polityków kolonii, zależnym przed wszystkim od osobistych poglądów. Negatywna ocena działań Kongresu podjęta przez przeciwników osłabienia wpływów Wielkiej Brytanii została zawarta w pamflecie duchownego Samuela Seasbury. Szczególnie negatywnie oceniana była decyzja o bojkocie handlowym, której duchowny przeciwstawiał cały szereg argumentów ekonomicznych. Według lojalistów decyzje polityków kolonii były zdradą interesów społeczeństwa. Odpowiedziom na krytykę lojalistów był tekst Aleksandra Hamiltona, przedstawiający punkt widzenia bliższy organizacji Sons of Liberty. Postrzega on działania Kongresu jako próbę ochrony praw mieszkańców kolonii zagrożonych działaniami metropolii. Autorzy obu tekstów zwracają się do farmerów – jednej z najliczniejszy grup społecznych starając się ich przekonać do swej oceny działalności Kongresu. Słowa kluczowe: Pierwszy Kongres Kontynentalny, Aleksander Hamilton, Samuel Seasbury, Trzynaście Kolonii, Stany Zjednoczone

creator: Kyiv International Institute of Sociology
title: Readiness of Ukrainians to Participate in Social Protest Actions (2009-2021)
description: The merged dataset contains the results of the monitoring of (repeated) public opinion surveys conducted by the Kyiv International Institute of Sociology in the period from 2009 to 2021 on people's willingness to participate in social protest actions.<br><br>To measure people's willingness to participate in social protests, the question "What social protest actions would you personally be willing to participate in? "was used, with the possibility of choosing any number of answers from the list of forms of protest (participation in election campaigns; collecting signatures for collective appeals (demands, calls); sanctioned meetings and demonstrations; threat of strike; boycott (refusal to comply with decisions of the administration, authorities); Unauthorised meetings and demonstrations; Participation in strikes; Hunger strikes; Picketing state institutions, blocking their work; Seizure of buildings; Creation of armed groups independent of the authorities; Other) or 'I am not ready to take part in any mass protest action'.<br><br>This question has been included in regular KIIS omnibus surveys, usually once a year.<br><br>All surveys were conducted with samples representative of the adult population of Ukraine (18 years and older), with an average sample size of about 2000 respondents. <br><br>For ease of analysis, the results of the individual surveys have been combined into a single dataset comprising 14 surveys with a total of 28,347 respondents.<br><br>This dataset contains the original raw data as a .SAV file (Ukrainian, English) and a converted .XLSX file with a codebook (Ukrainian, English).<br><br>The Documentation of Data Collection includes a description of the methodology and the main results of the survey.

creator: Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation, Center for Political Sociology
title: Survey of internally displaced persons in Western Ukraine (March/April 2022)
description: This data collection offers a large-scale survey of internally displaced persons in Western Ukraine a month after the start of the full-scale Russian war of aggression against Ukraine. The poll was conducted by the Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation in cooperation with the Center for Political Sociology. The poll was conducted in the form of face-to-face interviews from March 27 to April 5, 2022 in five western regions of Ukraine (Chernivtsi, Ivano-Frankivsk, Lviv, Ternopil, and Zakarpattia). A total of 1,000 internally displaced persons were interviewed (200 per region).<br><br>The survey questions cover emotional state, the experience of moving, live in the new place, support measures, and general political views.<br><br>This data collection contains the original survey data. The SPSS file (.sav) is the original file provided by the Ilko Kucheriv Democratic Initiatives Foundation. It has been exported into an Excel file. The content of the respective xlsx-file should be identical with the original sav-file. The sav-file contains the questions and answer options of the original questionnaire in Ukrainian. The original questionnaire and an English translation are also included in the Documentation of Data Collection. Each file has a size of less than 300 KB.<br><br>In this version some minor typos have been corrected.

creator: JSSAL
title: Çağlak Eker, 2023
description: This study investigated the attitudes of the students studying in high school education towards the music lesson and their expectations from their teachers in terms of participation in the lesson. The survey model was used in the design of this study, which included quantitative research methods. The sample group for the research consists of 354 students from 9th, 10th, and 11th grades at Esenevler Sehit Ibrahim Ates Anadolu High School in Ankara, Turkey, in the 2021–2022 academic year. Two scales that have been developed in relation to the topic were utilized to collect the data for the study; the Attitude Scale Toward Secondary Education Level Music Lesson and the Expectations from Teachers About Class Engagement. Mann-Whitney U Test for comparison of paired groups in data analysis, Kruskal Wallis H Test for comparison of more than two groups; Bonferroni Posthoc Test were used to determine the group that caused the difference. The bilateral link within the parameters of the research scales was assessed using Spearman’s Correlation Test. As a result, it was concluded that the awareness sub-dimension of the attitude affected expectations from teachers about class engagement, but there was no significant relationship between positive and negative attitudes.

creator: Nathalie Baudouin (deputy director)
title: Compagnie de l'Oiseau-Mouche
subject: Theatre Group
description: The history of L'Oiseau Mouche (“hummingbird”) began more than forty years ago and has ever since involved a team of around 55 people, including 23 actors and actresses with a learning disability. The company’s work has resulted in more than 50 productions staged more than 1700 times in France and internationally. L'Oiseau Mouche also involves two restaurants with 18 cooks and waiters with a learning disability. The theatre company was born in 1978 and became professional three years later, creating the first French artistic work facility for people with disabilities. Initially, the group explored just mime theatre, using spoken language sparingly until 1987, when the dramatic text was incorporated with the staging of Rapt by Philippe Vaernewich and Dramaticules by Beckett, directed by Stéphane Verrue. In 1995, the cooperation with Antonio Vigano began, resulting in three productions, among them Personnages. The play follows Luigi Pirandello’s Six Characters in Search of an Author, resulting in the group’s second most staged play (146 tens) and obtaining the Italian Stregagatto Award for “Best Play for Youths.” In the early 2000s, text became a vital element in the company’s work, resulting in the productions of Phèdre by Jean Racine and King Lear by William Shakespeare, staged by Sylvie Reteuna. During this time, the group settles in Roubaix, close to Lille (France). Among the following productions are The Mother by Berthold Brecht (director: François Delrue), L’Enfant de la Jungle after Rudyard Kipling’s famous novel, resulting in the company’s most staged play (154 times in six years), and The Odyssey by Homer, both directed by Christophe Bihel. A long-term collaboration with Christophe Piret was established in 2009 when L'Oiseau Mouche was incorporated in the fifth episode of In My House. In October 2011, the company began working with Cédric Orain to stage Sortir Du Corps (“Leave the Body”), exploring the singular language of author Valère Novarina. In January 2013 Christian Rizzo choreographs his 39th play, De quoi tenir jusqu’à l’ombre (premiere: 24.01.2014). The same year, L'Oiseau Mouche was officially contracted by the French Ministry of Culture and Communications, and in 2014, in collaboration with Florence Lavaud, the play The Steadfast Tin Soldier (premiere: 20.01.2014) was produced for youths, freely adapted from Hans Christian Andersen’s tale. The year 2018 is an important year for the company: among the celebration of their fortieth anniversary are the productions of Par la fenêtre (“Through the window”) by Aude Denis and Madisoning by Amélie Poirier. In 2019, the output of the company’s 50th play – Les Diables (“The Devils”) by Michel Schweizer – is celebrated. During the forty years since its creation, the company overpassed its initial goals: what seemed impossible to its pioneers of the 1970s has become the day-to-day business for this generation’s actors in L'Oiseau Mouche. At the beginning of 2020, Léonor Baudouin became director of the company, pursuing the aim of enforcing the rootedness of the company in the realm of performing arts. The pandemic put an end to the multiple current projects, significantly influencing the staging of the shows. The 2020-2021 season is nonetheless slated to be an exceptional time: L'Oiseau Mouche creates its next play, Vouger les lignes-histoires de cartes (director: Bérangère Vantusso), at the Festival d’Avignon. The piece will be shown at the opening of the 2021 Festival Mondial des Théâtres de Marionnettes in Charlevilles-Mézière, guaranteeing a strong visibility of the company. The company has also been in constant collaboration with Boris Charmatz centring around three projects which will be presented at the 2021 Festival d’Automne in Paris. Creation and Artistic Research The dynamic of their artistic creations is fundamental for the company and based on four core values: the encounter of the actors and the artists, companionship, the discovery of aesthetic pluralism, and the appreciation of long-term artistic partnerships; the act of choosing their collaborations is, therefore a special process. This is also why the company does not have a designated stage director. Artists from different disciplines are invited to cultivate aesthetic plurality, setting off a profoundly intimate selection process. Since 2008, the company has also developed another production axis, the Petites Formes (“Small Forms”), moving away from the stricter definition of “traditional” theatre. This possibility multiplies the productions and the opportunities for the actors to be cast. It also enables the company to reach out to audiences that do not go to the theatre usually. While attaining the artistic standards of the company, these Petites Formes are easier in the technical setting and can, therefore, be performed anywhere. The initiative benefits from the official support of the network forming the Métropole Européene de Lille. L'Oiseau Mouche also values external projects involving their actors who benefit from the supplementary experience, which is then transmitted to the rest of the company. For the same reason, L'Oiseau Mouche often engages in co-productions, pairing financial and administrative engagement with the actors’ integration. Said interconnectedness deepens inter-artistic ties and opens perspectives on new potential partnerships. Training The training process lies at the heart of L'Oiseau Mouche and is often inseparable from the company’s creation process: artists are invited to give workshops to the group’s actors, which is incidentally where the journey of future projects has often begun. These workshops are also the meeting point for long-term-employed actors and newcomers. The training program is centred around three elements: dancing, object theatre, and hybrid forms of music. Plastic and visual arts blend in theatre in a transdisciplinary manner.

creator: Francisco José Fernandez
title: Ti voglio bene Eugenio
subject: Diversity
description: Abstract: A middle-aged man with Down syndrome, Eugenio, volunteers at a hospital, where he is helping Laura, a girl who temporarily lost her ability to walk and talk due to a car accident. Meanwhile, he agrees to talk to a mother who is expecting a child with Down syndrome. However, he does not know that she is the daughter of Elena, a lost long friend with whom he was in love when he was young, and that he is going to help the two of them to reconcile. Details: The opening scene is a black screen with a dialogue in the background. Laura is arguing with Claudio while he is driving a car. She is shaken, claiming that the person that was selling them drugs tried to rape her, but she managed to get away. The conversation distracted Claudio, and the two of them got in a car accident. Laura escaped death, but now she is in a wheelchair, and even though she is conscious, she seems unable to understand and talk. One of the people taking care of her is Eugenio, a middle-aged man with Down syndrome who volunteers at the facility where Laura is being treated. Despite his condition, he lives a normal life. After living with his brother’s family, he decided to move out, and now he lives alone; he is occupied with many small jobs other than volunteering at the hospital, like gardening at the police station, and has a passion for books and cooking. A series of flashbacks bring us back to when he was a young man and introduce in the movie two friends him with whom he had a special bond even though they would tease him about his condition. With one of the two, Elena, he was actually in love. The other, Cristina, died because of lung cancer when they were still young. While she was sick, Eugenio assisted her at the hospital, and since then, he kept volunteering there. She turns out to be the mother of Laura and comes back to town to check on her recovery, even though they did not have a good relationship in the past. When she arrives at the hospital, she recognizes Eugenio while he is assisting Laura and decides to get in touch with him again, but she does not tell him that Laura is her daughter. Elena and Eugenio go out to dinner, and when they go back to her old family’s villa, she keeps flirting with him and even tries to take Eugenio’s clothes off, but he rejects her because she is drunk. Meanwhile, one family that is expecting a child with Down syndrome comes to visit him to get to know his experience with the condition and try to decide if they want to keep the baby. When they ask him what he would do if he were to make such a decision, he smiles and tries to show them the normal life that he is conducting. However, Eugenio confesses later to Elena that he did not really feel that way. At the hospital, Laura is doing physical therapy but seems unable to respond or react. However, Eugenio does not lose faith, and during his shifts, he feeds her and tries to get her to recognize what she is eating and communicate with her eyes. Claudio, whose friend who survived the car accident and escaped, comes back to visit her at the hospital, and when he crosses paths with her mother, she flares up and gets into a fight with him while they are accusing each other of whose fault Laura’s accident was. He, in fact, blames her and her husband for not taking enough care of Laura while she was growing up and filled up with rage, hits her. When she shows up at Eugenio’s door with a swollen lip, Elena tells Eugenio the real reason why she had come back. So, he gets angry because she had let him think that she had come back to visit him and because she abandoned her daughter. Moved by Eugenio’s reproaches, she tries to visit her daughter but rejects her. Eugenio then tries to mediate, and he discovers that, twenty years ahead, Elena had to leave because she was pregnant with a much older man whom she had to marry to make her father happy. Her biggest remorse is that she could not help Laura when her dad was abusing her, and therefore, she had to escape. So, Eugenio convinces them to give each other another chance, and, eventually, one day, Elena agrees to accompany Laura to visit Claudio at the penitentiary, and from that moment, the mother and the daughter start to reconcile. The ending scene shows that Eugenio, Elena, and Laura, who in the meantime recuperated her mobility and her ability to talk, are all living together. Meanwhile, the woman expecting a child with Down syndrome decided to go through with the pregnancy and just gave birth.

creator: Vianney Lebasque
title: Chacun pour tous
subject: Sports
description: Abstract: The French Comedy Chacun Pour Tous (2018) tells the story of the French national team of Basketball ID (“Intellectual Disabilities”) participating in the 2000 Sydney Summer Paralympics. National coach Martin is desperately looking for capable members for his team; to create a competitive squad, he recruits additional non-disabled amateur basketball players, with whom the team eventually competes in Sydney. The narration deals with the individual experiences of the disabled and non-disabled players during the tournament. The film is based on true events: At the Sydney Paralympics 2000, the Spanish Basketball ID team won a gold medal with ten non-disabled players. The fraud was discovered, and the medal had to be given to the second place, Russia. Details: The film opens with Martin, coach of France’s national basketball ID team, desperately trying to recruit players for his team in disabled facilities after some members have left the team. In order to stay competitive and to preserve the French association for Basketball ID, Martin, initially against the wishes of his co-coach Sami, makes a plan to compete in the Paralympics with non-disabled players. The two places an ad and recruit amateur basketball players Stan, Pippo, André, Malik, and Michel in a banlieue. The group meets Martin’s plans with initial suspicion but eventually agrees to the plot. The plan is not confided (for now) to the remaining disabled players, Yohan and Freddie, nor to the team psychologist, Julia, who is also Yohan’s sister. In secret, Martin trains the new team members not only in basketball skills but also in a pseudo-disabled habitus and he is, which is supposed to help the team pass background checks. The players acquire supposedly disabled behaviours and successfully pass the entrance exam. Parallel to these preparations, Martin’s private life is shown, which is marked by the care of his physically disabled daughter Alice. The team travels to Sydney, and the tournament begins. A gap between the disabled and non-disabled players, marked by a lack of understanding and hostility, can be overcome through sporting success and a slow bonding between the members. In particular, the Yohan-Stan and Freddie-Pippo relationships evolve into close and mindful friendships. Additionally, romances seem to develop between Stan and Yohan’s sister Julia and between Pippo and another athlete, Amie, who sits in a wheelchair. At the same time, the entire team faces the challenge of not letting their façade fall, and situations repeatedly arise in which the team becomes conspicuous through “unusual” behaviour. Corresponding moments, for example, when Pippo, Stan, Yohan, and Freddie go to a party with other disabled athletes, repeatedly provide dicey situations. After the party, a one-night stand occurs between Pippo and Amie, with Pippo pretending to be non-disabled. General suspicions rise among officials, journalists, and disabled players. The French team plays exceptionally well and sometimes wins by too much. During the semi-final, Julia discovers the newly recruited players are not disabled. Horrified, she confronts Martin, who does not want to see the faults in his actions. Drunk Julia tells the secret to a Russian stranger in a hotel bar - who does not understand her since she speaks French. Stan seeks Julia out to talk to her about the secret and put it into perspective, to which she does not respond. Martin gets drunk with the non-handicapped players in a bar the night before the final. Freddie begins a romance with a Russian player, Paprika. Julia seeks to talk to Stan and Pippo, and the three make up. As Martin talks to his daughter on the phone, it dawns on him that winning the finals would mean too much attention. He tells the team to lose on purpose. At first, everything goes according to plan. The other final team, Russia, is in the lead at halftime. Julia then finds out that the Russian team is also non-disabled - her flirt from the bar the day before, who was obviously not disabled, is one of the players. Accordingly, the team changes tactics: instead of playing badly on purpose, all members get the best out of each other and eventually defeat the Russian team by two free throws of Yohan. With the final win, however, the team flies off the handle. A horde of journalists confronts Martin at the airport - he sends his staff on the plane and faces the press.

creator: Giorgio Romano
title: Detective per caso
subject: Friendship
description: Abstract: Giulia is a girl with Down syndrome with a passion for crime stories. When her cousin Pietro gets involved in an armed robbery and disappears, she investigates with her group of friends to find him and prove his innocence. They face gangsters and escape dangerous situations, overcoming their fears and showing their loyalty to one another. Eventually, they manage to find the criminals, free Pietro, and go back to hang out happily all together. Details: The movie opens showing a car chase in the streets of Rome between two police officers and two criminals, who eventually manage to escape. One of them has his face covered, and the other is Pietro, one of the story’s protagonists. The following scene flashes back to the previous week in order to tell the events that led Pietro to the crime scene. He is a young man who hangs out with his cousin, Giulia Santeramo, and their group of friends at their regular bar, “San Salvador.” Giulia is a girl with Down syndrome who works at the lost and found in Rome’s main train station and has a passion for crime stories. The other components of their group are Valeria, a girl dreaming of becoming an influencer; Marco, also called “Panico” because of his constant fears; Sandro and Oreste. One day, after hanging out in San Salvador, Pietro saves Marta, a girl addicted to drugs, when some dealers to whom she owes money approach her. She tries to convince him not to get involved in her chaotic life, but he is already falling in love with her and starts dating her instead. Giulia, who is very close to her cousin Pietro, worries a lot about him and does not like Marta. In the meantime, she fails to give enough attention to Antonio, her boyfriend. In fact, she does not invite him to the upcoming charity party organized in San Salvador. At the party, Pietro gets into a fight with Giulia because he asks her to lend him some money to help Marta, and she refuses and tells him she disapproves of their relationship. After the fight, both are very sad and while Giulia calls Antonio and goes home crying, Pietro goes back into the bar and gets drunk. The next morning, Giulia receives a visit from her uncle, Pietro’s father, who tells her that Pietro disappeared. They both get called at the police station, where they are informed that Pietro was involved in an armed robbery that took place in San Salvador, the crime shown at the opening scene. Giulia is determined to find Pietro and prove his innocence, so she recruits her group of friends to start investigating. The investigation leads them to get involved in dangerous situations. First, they break into Marta’s father’s house, looking for clues, and then they meet up with some gangsters to find out where she is. Finally, they find her in a rehabilitation clinic and ask her for information about where Pietro could be, but by doing so, they put her in danger by making her traceable to some gangsters who want to harm her. From visiting Marta, they only obtain one clue on where to find Pietro: they need to find a man named Ivan. In the meantime, Pietro wakes up at the robber’s house, Ivan, but because of the hangover, he does not remember much about the night before. After a couple of days, he realizes that Ivan is kidnapping him. Giulia and her friends are about to give up on the investigation and leave it to the police, who trace Ivan’s house, save Pietro before nothing bad happens to him, and arrest them both. However, Giulia keeps looking for clues and figures out that actually the owner of the San Salvador, Giovanni Malatesta, was involved in the robbery at his own bar. Instead of informing her friends or the police, Giulia decides to head to San Salvador and face Giovanni all alone, putting herself in danger once again. While Giovanni threatens Giulia, she texts her friends asking for help. They inform the police and head up there, facing their fear in order to save her. Meanwhile, Ivan and Pietro confirm Giulia’s theory at the police station: the robbery was actually a fraud planned by Giovanni and Marta to gain some money. Later, Marta, convinced by Pietro, opted out of the plan and joined a rehabilitation clinic. The police finally arrest Giovanni Malatesta, and the case is solved. The group of friends that Antonio and Marta also join can go back to enjoy some calm and happy moments together.

creator: Christian Chavagneux
title: Théâtre Instant Présent
subject: Theatre Group
description: Théâtre Instant Présent is an artistic and political project initiated in 2005 and has since been actively engaged in various activities across France. The group’s primary objective is to promote theatrical engagement for people from all walks of life, encompassing professionals and amateurs, focusing on those often distanced from cultural institutions. Consequently, the company offers a range of programs and initiatives, including: 1. Productions featuring individuals in situations of disability, exclusion, or illness. 2. Training opportunities for professionals, such as social workers and psychologists, who aim to incorporate drama workshops into social, medical-social, or healthcare settings. 3. Acting workshops for professionals from various artistic disciplines, including actors, singers, and dancers. 4. Workshops designed for amateur participants. The artistic creations at Théâtre Instant Présent are grounded in improvisation and the clown figure. The theatre aims to connect with reality, emphasizing sensitivity, poetic expression, and humour. Productions featuring marginalized individuals, social workers, and actors represent a fusion of artistic, social, and communal approaches. Collaborating with individuals facing disabilities, exclusion, or illness allows those who have been silenced or unable to communicate to express their unique experiences and perspectives on the world, sharing them with the audience, which results in both personal and collective emancipation. This emancipation is an individual journey, as acting allows individuals to explore new emotions, sensations, and thoughts, breaking free from potentially alienating existences. Amateur actors regain control of their place and voice within society. Language, voice, words, movement, stage presence, and active listening all play a supportive role in this process. Collective emancipation occurs through the staging of improvisations that take place during workshops. The artistic project intertwines theatre with reality, addressing specific challenges participants face (e.g., disability, exclusion, unemployment) and universal themes (e.g., love, solidarity, difference, sexuality). These productions prompt inquiries into the concept of living together, reflecting a noble understanding of politics: How do we coexist harmoniously? The emancipatory dimension extends to the audience, offering a fresh perspective on individuals occasionally perceived as “the others.” The theatrical representation encourages critical thinking, fosters sharing, encourages empathy, facilitates dialogue, and enables self-expression. In addition to its commitment to social theatre, Théâtre Instant Présent aims to cultivate the development of social theatre facilitators, potentially allowing the establishment of workshops for marginalized individuals facing disabilities, thereby making theatre practice accessible to all.

creator: Christina Schiewe
title: Be My Baby
subject: Motherhood
description: Abstract: In the 2014 film “Be My Baby,” director Christina Schiewe tells the story of Nicole, a self-confident young woman with Down syndrome who wants to become a mother. Details: 18-year-old Nicole lives with her mother, Monique. Nicole’s mother attends university and works part-time as a cashier to earn enough money. Nicole’s grandmother supports Monique financially and occasionally watches Nicole while Monique goes to work. Nicole works at the vocational school for people with disabilities. At the university, Monique attends a lecture by faculty member Dr. Olaf Schnier. Olaf and Monique also meet privately outside the university and start a love affair. Contrary to what her mother assumes, Nicole has sexual needs. Her sexual interest becomes evident in various situations. For example, Nicole is interested in a brochure with sexual content at work or throws air kisses to her supposed steady boyfriend and work colleague, Mani. In addition, Nicole also wants to start a family of her own, ideally with the boy next door, Nick, who she is in love with. On the way to work, Nicole sees a woman on the bus with her, increasing Nicole’s desire to have a family. However, her mother thinks this a bad idea, as she continues to see Nicole as a child and not as a woman. Moreover, her grandmother wants to go one step further and sterilize Nicole. Nick, who has known Nicole for a long time, is just 15 years old and is currently studying for his high school diploma. He is an outsider and under constant pressure to please everyone, especially his father and friends. Nicole sees something special in Nick and gives him the affection and unconditional love he needs. Eventually, they sleep together, and Nicole gets pregnant accidentally. The pregnancy is first noticed when Nicole vomits several times for no supposed reason, and Monique takes her to the doctor. Surprised by this, Monique confronts Nicole in the presence of Nicole’s grandmother and demands to know the baby’s father. Nicole admits that the father is Nick. Nick does not want to know about Nicole’s pregnancy and denies being the father. But one thing is certain for Nicole: she wants to keep the baby and thus fights for her right to self-determination. While everyone is in favour of abortion, Nicole goes on a hunger strike until Nick stands by her and accepts his paternity. Nicole eventually gives birth to a healthy child, warmly welcomed by both families, including Nicole’s grandmother and Nick’s family.

creator: Éric Toledano
title: Hors Normes
subject: Caregiving
description: Abstract: The film relates to the association called “The Voice of the Fair,” which takes care of mentally or developmentally disabled people, especially adolescents. Bruno Haroche, a French Jew who founded the association, needs to deal with various departments of the French Government as they are trying to shut the organization down. Details: Bruno Haroche is a busy man. Due to his position as the director of the association “The Voice of the Fair,” he is occupied with managing the supervisors of his home for people who are “special.” Furthermore, Bruno cares about his patients and spends his days looking after people like Joseph, who loves washing machines and can’t take the train on his own as he pulls the emergency trigger every time he drives. Or adolescents like Valentin, who is autistic and needs to wear a helmet as he wants to hit his head against objects. The patients, who are living right at the association or at their parent’s houses, are taken out on excursions like skating or horse therapy with supervisors of the association. These supervisors are young people from the districts around the Jewish Association of Bruno. The education on how to deal with the patients is getting supervisors from Bruno’s partner, Malik, who calls the informal school “The ladder.” Both “The Ladder” and “The Voice of the Fair” are informal organizations with no official permission to take care of the “special kids,” as Bruno calls his patients. Bruno doesn’t want to calm them down with sedatives to guarantee that the patients aren’t a threat to themselves or their families. However, many other hospitals and organizations are practising this, as it is comfortable and cheaper regarding expenses and staff. Even though Bruno has a working concept, which consists of treating his patients with respect and putting every patient with a personal supervisor at their side, the inspectors of the French Government are trying to sue Bruno and his staff for child abuse since they aren’t formally trained. After visiting the association and speaking to parents and hospitals where the patients usually come from, the inspectors note the importance of Bruno’s project. His association admits the “hopeless” cases that no other organization wants to receive, giving every patient the chance to live a dignified life. Finally, Bruno can continue his work and improve the quality of his patients’ lives, although his love life suffers from the constant availability for “his kids.”

creator: Dr. Soledad Pereyra
title: Movies
subject: Films
description: The following is a metadata subcollection on European films involving artists with cognitive disabilities. This subcollection was compiled between 2020 and 2023 as part of the project “Erzählung, Erwartung, Erfahrung. Behinderung im zeitgenössischen europäischen Theater und Film” (EEE) or “Narrative, Expectation, and Experience: Disability in Contemporary European Theatre and Film,” which was funded by the German Research Foundation DFG (Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft; project number 429281822) and directed by Prof. Dr. Susanne Hartwig of the University of Passau in Germany. The data collection was coordinated by Dr. Soledad Pereyra, University of Passau.

creator: Pierre-Jules Billon (artistic collaboration)
title: Cabaret des frissons garantis
description: Abstract: The performance combines various theatrical acts, live music, and song elements, creating a menu-like sequence. The texts, by Valère Novarina, Pierre Dac, Alphonse Allais, and Roland Topor, are complemented by music composed by Henri Salvador and Nino Ferrer, among others. Throughout the performance, ensemble members cook a meal backstage, which is later served to the audience.

creator: Marc Bryssinck
title: Episode 2: Jaspers vader keurt de relatie van zijn zoon af
subject: Love
description: Abstract: Jasper and Tina start a love relationship. This fact arouses the enthusiasm of their co-workers and the nerves of Jasper’s parents. Tytgat Chocolat needs a solution to save from bankruptcy. To this end, Roman created the “Golden Truffle”, an initiative that ensures short-term profits and avoids the dismissal of the packaging team. The factory situation improves, but the police announce to Katarina and Tina that they must leave the country, and they are arrested. Details: The beginning of the episode takes place in Jasper’s dream. He is on the karaoke stage in front of three female coworkers with their backs turned. He begins to list some positive characteristics of him, and two of the women turn around, smiling at him. However, there is one of them, Tina, who still turns her back on him. Suddenly, she starts to repeatedly say that she dumps him. Jasper awakes from his nightmare. Her mother, Nikki, is knocking on the door and encourages him to eat something. Jasper gets up from bed and goes to the bathroom. Raoul is there, too and sees how Jasper takes one of his most expensive perfumes and puts on it. Raoul says that he and his mother should know Tina. Jasper feels pressured, and he responds to him that it is too soon for that. Jasper goes to work, and everybody there makes reference to the kiss between Tina and him at the karaoke party. When he arrives in the changing room, he sees Tina. They start to talk, and they both say to each other that they need to have a conversation. In the changing room, everybody is looking at them, so they decide to go outside. There, they talk about his relationship, and they decide to officially start being a couple. Then they start to kiss. In another area of the factory, Roman has to go to a meeting that Andy has convened without Roman’s knowledge. Roman is confused because of that, and he goes to his executive office to attend to it. The meeting has already started, and Mr. Müller, a market analyst, is projected and streamed on the office wall. He encourages Tytgat Chocolat firm to expand its distribution to Germany through complete automation of the packaging area. Roman starts to feel nervous, and he gets up from the table. He looks through the window while the rest of the members are greedily negotiating. Roman sees through the window that Jasper and Tina are kissing each other outside. After a few seconds, Roman cuts the conversation and establishes that he disagrees with the negotiation because it involves the dismissal of the Packers, which he is not willing to accept. Jasper and Tina are back in the packaging area, and they announce that they are now together in a love relationship. The Packers applaud and cheer them on. With excitement, Django throws up in the air his little glitter ball. Katarina goes outside the factory to see her brother. He arrives in a car accompanied by another man from Kosovo, who informs Katarina that she and her daughter must leave the Schengen area as soon as possible if they do not want to be deported to Kosovo. Katarina refuses to accept that, and she leaves the car angrily. Roman is in the hall of the factory and sees Katarina pass by without greeting him. Suddenly, he looks at the television in the hall, where employers can upload photos online, and he sees that Crispjn is uploading a photo of Django playing in the packaging area. He goes there immediately and finds his employees playing. He tells the packing team that they have no idea about what is coming and that they have to produce more. He forbids the presence of toys and takes Django’s glitter ball with him. At night, Roman is at home, and he can not sleep. He gets up from bed and, goes to his mother’s room and finds her looking at an old photo album of the enterprise Tytgat Chocolat. In the album, there is a picture of Indra, and Roman starts to remember out loud a past situation in which Indra was generous and gave lots of chocolate cups to a group of children visitors to the factory. This generous gesture inspires Roman, who goes to a shed outside his house in order to develop one idea that the past gesture of his sister has inspired. After some leisure time spent with her friends, Tina comes back home with her mother. When they both arrive, they notice that the door of the entrance has been forced. Inside, they see that all their staff is bagged. Katarina sees a book in which there is a note that says: “Have a good trip!”. The next day, Tina is going to Jasper’s house to have dinner with his family. The parents are puzzled by the displays of affection between their son and Tina, although they try to keep the encounter flowing. Tina mentions the idea of having children and the desire to live independently with Jasper, and these two facts make Jasper’s parents to be worried. After the dinner, Jasper accompanies Tina to the bus stop, but a car shows up. The driver is the same person who met Katarina in the parking lot of the factory. He says that he has been sent by his mother and that he will drive Tina home. She gets into the car. Jasper goes back home and hears that his parents are arguing. Raoul says that Tina is not for Jasper and that she wants things that Jasper will not be able to provide because he is a child. Nikki claims that this is Jasper’s decision and that he is growing up. Jasper, who is on the other side of the door, goes upstairs. Tina arrives home with two tickets to Kosovo that the man who drove her home gave to her. Katarina gets scared and tells her daughter not to go outside alone ever again. Roman is in his house, and he has already finished the design of the project that he created to save the factory benefits: the contest of the “Golden Truffle.” He explains it to his mother and his wife. According to the spirit of generosity linked to the Tytgat tradition, he created this initiative in which three golden truffles will be distributed randomly in the Tytgat boxes. The winner receives an amount of money for ten times his weight in chocolate. The next morning, Roman explains the idea to the rest of the partners of the factory and establishes that the packing will not be automated. Andy does not like this idea, and his grandfather, who is also a partner of the factory, tells him to continue in secret with the development of the project linked to automation and distribution in Germany. Two weeks later, Roman’s initiative was a success, and sales increased. Roman celebrates it by giving each of the packers a box of chocolates from the production batch of the “Golden Truffle”. Later, Tina is called to Roman’s office because the police are there asking for Katarina and her. They say that both the mother and the daughter must voluntarily abandon the country within seven days. Otherwise, they will be deported. After that, Roman´s secretary tells him that the television media is in the factory because there is a first winner. After the prize event, Roman calls his brother Lode and asks for his help as a lawyer in the case of Katarina and Tina. They both go to have dinner and talk about it. In the beginning, Lode is not really convinced about doing it, but suddenly, the packaging team shows up in the restaurant since they went to have some leisure time. Lode looks at Tina, and he and his brother agree on the similarities between Tina and her dead sister, Indra. After some thought, Lode decides to help Katarina and her daughter. A few days later, Lode goes to Katarina´s house and talks with her about their legal situation. Lode asks Katarina about their previous situation in Kosovo, but she refuses to testify. In the factory, Roman delivers the second prize. Lode informs him that there is no choice for Katarina because of her ambiguous past, of which the Belgian police are well aware. Louise and Nikki are at home, and the phone rings. It is Jasper, and he tells her parents that he is not going back home that day because he will spend the night at Tina´s. His parents get nervous and ask Jasper to pass the phone to Katarina. They try to make sure that they will be under her supervision. Despite this, Louise does not want Jasper to sleep there, but Nikki agrees on the phone and hangs up. After the phone call, both parents watch the TV news, and they find out that Tina and Katarina are at risk of deportation. After that, Roman shows up on the news, and he calls for a demonstration the next day in the factory to demand the non-deportation of his two workers. That night, Jasper and Tina sleep together. The next morning, Jasper goes back to his home. He sees his father in the garden. There, Louise reminds his son of the failure of his previous partners and questions his feelings, saying that he is too young to know what he wants. Jasper asks him when he know that he loves Nikki, and Louise responds that he knew when he was 24, to which Jasper replies: “Dad, I am 23”. On the day of the demonstration, Louise and Jasper go to pick up Tina and Katarina to go there together. When they arrive, they see a police van. Tina and her mother are being arrested. Jasper runs to the van and looks at Tina from outside. They both are scared and in shock. The van starts to move, and Jasper stares at it, driving away.

creator: Filip Lenaerts
title: Episode 3: #1.3
subject: Migration
description: Abstract: Tina and Katarina are arrested in a refugee centre, and Jasper escapes several times to visit them, but they are finally deported to Kosovo. The third golden truffle of the contest does not appear, and Tytgat Chocolat begins to fall victim to rumours that relate the company to fraud. Roman contracts someone to impersonate the third winner in order to avoid the company's bad image. However, the packaging team found out that the third truffle was in Tina´s locker, so she was the real third winner. Roman tries to silence their workers, but Jasper´s gang starts to plan a way to go after Tina. Details: Jasper is dreaming that Tina and he are dancing in the karaoke dressed as bride and groom. Afterwards, he awakes. This morning, his parents see that the case of Tina and her mother appears in the newspaper: both are in a refugee centre in Steenokkerzeel. Raoul tells Jasper that he has just prepared some documents to make a visit to the centre due to the fact that non-family members of inmates need visiting permission. Jasper does not want to wait, and he goes secretly by himself to the train station in order to travel to where Tina is. At the station, Jasper shows his special disability trip card to the ticket seller, who informs him that he needs a supervisor to be able to travel. After that, Jasper knows a blind man who is sitting in the station hall. The man decides to help Jasper by acting as his supervisor and helps Jasper to buy a ticket. He also informs Jasper that in order to arrive at Steenokkerzeel, he must transfer to a bus in Brussels. Once in Brussels, Jasper remains on his own. The hall of the station is crowded, and people are in a hurry. No one helps Jasper when he asks for the bus station until two young boys ask him if he is lost. Both accompany Jasper to the bus, and he takes it. In the factory, Roman has a meeting with Andy and his grandfather. Andy tells them that a newspaper announced a suspicion about the context of the “Golden Truffle” since there is no third winner appearing. Roman calls the person who sold him the chips implanted in the golden truffles and asks about the GPS function that the seller promised him. The seller tries to track the chips, but he can only find two of them, and he informs Roman that sometimes the GPS function does not work well. Due to the fact that the producer of the chips is a friend of Roman and not an official enterprise, he cannot be reported to the police without tarnishing the name of the Tytgat Chocolat factory. Then, Roman decides to resort to fraud. He buys a fourth golden truffle and a new false winner to appear in the news and quell the rumours. Jasper arrives at the refugee centre, and he asks to see Tina, but the receptionist informs him that it is not possible because they are neither family nor does he have a visit permission. Jasper becomes furious and starts shouting that he wants to see Tina. The plant manager arrives and negotiates with Jasper: he can see Tina for ten minutes; after that, he must leave. Jasper agrees. Finally, he meets Tina, but they are separated by a fence. Jasper asks Tina to marry him. This way, they can be related, and visits are easier to make. Tina accepts, and after that, the police return Jasper to his home, where his parents are worriedly waiting for him. Jasper tells them that he has proposed to Tina, and Raoul gets angry. He tries to relax and explains to his son that he is not able to do that because the law establishes a prolonged minority of age for people with cognitive disabilities as legal subjects. Jasper goes to his room, and the parents start a discussion. The next day in the factory, one of the female packers goes to Tina's locker in order to get her things out and prepare them for the new worker. While she is doing that, she finds a box of chocolates that Roman gave to her and each of the workers because of the “Golden Truffle” context. The box falls to the floor by accident, and one golden truffle appears from it. The worker runs to tell Jasper about it. Jasper takes the golden truffle and goes to the station to take a train back to Steenokkerzeel. While this happens, the third false prize is being delivered to an actor who plays as a winner. When Jasper arrives at the centre, he asks to see Tina, but the receptionist informs him that Tina and her mother left the centre this morning and started the deportation to Kosovo. After that, Jasper returns home on his own. Roman has several interviews to find a new chocolate taster, but he is not convinced about anyone. While he is talking with a candidate, Jasper arrives at his office with Tina´s golden truffle. Roman stops the meeting immediately and asks the candidate to go. Roman establishes vehemently that the contest is finished and there is no chance for Tina, but Jasper insists that Tina has to receive her prize. Roman asks Jasper to give him the golden truffle and says that he will try to do something. The package team discusses the fraud of Roman due to the existence of four golden truffles and three prizes. After that, some of them, including Jasper, go to Roman´s office to ask for an explanation. Roman avoids the conversation, and Jasper shouts that they want the prize for Tina. After that, Roman threatens to fire them if they do not go back to work. Cedric, the packaging manager, stares at him and says that he would never have expected that from him. This night, Jasper lies self-absorbed on his bed. He thinks about a plan to solve the injustice situation with Tina. Next Saturday is the karaoke night, and Cedric, Jasper, Max, and Crispijn decide that they will leave the city and go after Tina. The co-workers start their plan to escape. They pool money together and prepare the lie that they will tell their parents to have time to run away. On the karaoke night, the packaging team meets and enjoys while Jasper goes in secret to Roman´s office and takes Tina´s golden truffle with him. After the event, people go back home, but Cedric, Jasper, Max, and Crispijn start their trip.

creator: Marc Bryssinck
title: Episode 4: Met vallen en opstaan reizen de inpakkers door Duitsland
subject: Work
description: Abstract On their way to Kosovo, Jasper, Spijker, Cedrik, Max, and Django live the advantages and disadvantages of being on their own. They are able to survive on Roman's stolen credit card, but it is cancelled. In the factory, Roman discovers that their employees have stolen not only his credit card but also the golden truffle that compromises the image of Tytgat Chocolat. Jasper and his friends know Harry in a hostel in Munich. He is accompanied by a motor rider group, which is willing to transport them. Details Jasper, Spijker, Cedrik and Max are escaping through the woods. Their plan is to travel to Kosovo by any means they are able to find during the journey and with the help of the money they saved the previous weeks. The four of them are dressed in scout uniforms. Since Spijker is the tallest and the only one without physical signs of Down's Syndrome, he will pretend to be the guide of his companions. The gang arrives at a transport truck parking, and Spijker convinces one trucker to take them with him. Nevertheless, Django, another coworker of Tytgat Chocolat, was following them until the parking lot, so he ended up joining the journey. The trucker decides to stop after a while in a road bar. Jasper thinks that it is not a good idea to stop because it delays the travel, but the trucker needs to rest, and, in the end, Spijker convinces Jasper to stop as well. When the gang goes into the bar, everybody looks at them. The trucker asks for a beer for each one, but Spijker says that he is no longer drinking alcohol due to his past problems with it. Max makes fun of him and insinuates that he is gay for not doing so. Spijker gets angry, and he drinks his beer in two shots. After this, he starts ordering more beers. In the meantime, Django goes crazy with the slot machine and spends all his money, and Max flirts and dances with a girl at the bar. Jaspers is sitting on a table alone. He is lost in thought with his back to what is happening. In the bar, there is a man who also likes the woman Max is dancing with. He approaches Spijker and asks him to tell Max to stop dancing with the girl, but Spijker is drunk and responds rudely: “You tell him, asshole”. Both start a fight, and the trucker tries to separate them. In the end, the gang and the trucker are thrown out of the bar. After this night, Jasper and his companions say goodbye to the trucker, and they start to walk in line on one side of the road with Spijker staggering behind them. They arrive at Maastricht train station, and once there, Jasper takes a look at the map to decide which would be the next destination. He finds out that there is a train to Munich that fits with their route to Kosovo. As Jasper had to deal with buying tickets in the past to go to see Tina, he now knows how the ticket machines work, but when he selects the purchase of five tickets, he realizes that the amount of money exceeds the cash that the entire group has. However, Max shows the group Roman’s credit card that he stole from their boss the karaoke night. Jasper is not sure about using it, but he accepts, saying that they should return the money to Roman when they can. On the train, they are sleeping except for Max, who is staring at Jasper. When Jasper awakes, Max tells him that he wants a part of the prize money since he found the golden truffle. Jasper refuses due to Tina’s right to the entire prize. When the group arrives in Munich, Cedrik realises that his GPS watch, which is necessary to be guided, is out of batteries. Cedrik, Max and Django go outside the station to buy it while Jasper and Spijker wait for them in the station hall. The gang have one and a half hours until the last train of the day to Belgrado, their next destination, departs. In the city, the three coworkers are really entertained by street performers and the leisure facilities that the public space of Munich provides. When they go to buy the batteries, Max finds a knife in the shop, and he decides to add it to the purchase. After that, Cedrik, Django, and Max are attracted by the consumerism of a street full of shops and the Roman’s endless credit cards. After buying new clothes, Cedrik tells Django and Max that they should go back to the station, but Max is hungry and influences Django to go to a restaurant with him, and Cedrik follows them with resignation. This morning, Roman and his wife decide to go to a restaurant. There, Roman finds out that he no longer has his credit card, so he cancels the payment transactions immediately. This fact prevents Cedrik from paying the bill in the restaurant, and it delays a lot of their return to the train station.
